subject: Re: [junit] Tests naming
msgSnippet: So said  Kirill Maximov  on  2003-01-27 -------------------- ... flow ... should ... ordinary ... basic ... number ... to ... per ... I suppose we understand
messageBody:
So said Kirill Maximov on 2003-01-27 --------------------

>On 0, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@...> wrote:
>> Kirill!
>>
>> <snip />
>> >>> Generally there is one test per use case scenario (different
flow
>> >>> through the use case). Choosing to write more or fewer tests
should
>> be
>> >>> done thoughtfully.
>> >>
>> >> In my experience, there are several alternative flows for a
ordinary
>> >> use case. And I see reasonable to test at least two of them:
basic
>> >> flow and error flow. What do you think?
>>
>> Usually there are three kinds of flows:
>>
>> 1. The usual flow
>> 2. Alternate usual flows
>> 3. Error flows
>>
>> I use the term "use case scenario" to mean a path through a use case
>> with many flows. Each "flow" is a use case scenario. I believe that
>> this is the standard UML term. When I say "use case scenario", it is
>> now clear what I mean.
>>
>> Generally, the goal is to write one Customer Test per use case
>> scenario. There may even be additional tests, depending on the
number
>> of different representative data points along the way.
>>
>> I prioritize as follows:
>>
>> 1. Usual flow test
>> 2. Fatal error flow tests
>> 3. Normal alternative flow tests
>> 4. Non-fatal error flow tests
>> 5. Others
>>
>> If there are, for example, 20 scenarios for a use case, then I need
to
>> sit down and decide whether the use case is too big.
>
> OK, now I see what you mean. Sorry, actually I've read your text not

> as "test case per user case scenario" but "test case per use case".
> Now, I still suggest having a package per use case and test class
per
> use case scenario.

I suppose we understand each other now. "Each use case scenario is
captured by at least one Customer Test." I don't say anything about
TestCase classes yet.

> Now about "too big" part. I'm not sure if you can do anything with
use
> case size itself. You can implement scenarios one-by-one, in order
you
> suggested, and make each flow a separate story. But all of them
> still belong to the same use case! From this point of view, it is
right
> to have Customer test per scenario.

I agree that some use cases are just big, although they may be able to
be decomposed into smaller use cases, depending on the details.

Again, depending on how one defines "scenario", one may need to write
many Customer Tests for one scenario, especially if different input
data materially affects the flow. (One could argue that this creates a
distinct scenario, and I generally agree, but I have to allow for the
fact that different people use the same terms differently.)

<snip />
>> >> - It is easier to get full list of existing functional tests if
we
>> put
>> >> each test case into a single class. Getting the list is quite
usual
>> >> task requested by QA department or customer (or I'm wrong here?)
>>
>> Certainly this is a good idea. There must be a way to present the
list
>> of currently-implemented Customer Tests to groups like QA. Dividing
the
>> tests among classes is one way to achieve this. Some kind of xDoclet
>> thing would be another. (Step in, Mr. Gemkow, to provide some
>> information here.)
>
> I'll try to look at it. But, as far as I expect, this tool separates
> the test description from code. And I envision the situation when
> "copy class" or "copy method" feature will be used without updating
> the description. To have incorrect test/class name is quite more
> noticable, than having incorrect javadoc and such.

No, indeed; however, a Customer Test's name is not a function of the
structure of the software; rather it is a function of the words used to
describe the system's behavior. Consider the case of the original C3
application. They used the Bin, Part, Station metaphor and named their
classes that way; but it's still a Payroll application and I can't
imagine that the Customer Tests mentioned Bin, Part and Station! Surely
the Customer Tests "spoke" the domain language of payroll: cheque,
payee, employee, deduction, and so on.

In short, Programmer Test names reflect the design; Customer Test names
reflect the domain.

<snip />
>> If I am in that situation and I cannot find a test fixture to match
my
>> current needs, then I build a new one and let the team refactor it
as
>> they come across it. Eventually, someone will feel the pain of not
>> having the right test fixture and will find the problem.
>
> Good point. But it should be a spirit in the team to fix tests of
> another team member as soon as the see duplication in the test code.

This is part of the definition of the term "team". Anything else is a
"group". :)

<snip />
>> >>> I have to say that your list of points is excellent and should
be
>> >>> turned into a short article on the subject.
>> >>
>> >> Thank you very much. Actually, I thought about it and I'll
possibly
>> >> try to write one.
>>
>> I am more than willing to edit it, if you need some help.
>
> Thank you for the offer. BTW, is is OK to post draft on the list
> for feedback? Possibly someone else will also want to comment.

I don't mind if they don't mind.

Have fun with it. I have my own writing to do. :)
